paragraphs.text: With the lexer, the decision to use my own code was fairly obvious. A lexer is such a trivial program that not writing my own felt almost as silly as not writing my own ‘left-pad’.
paragraphs.name: fea9
789a
paragraphs.text: There are two major types of languages: compiled and interpreted:

paragraphs.name: 73f6
paragraphs.text: “I have absolutely no idea where I would even start” is something I hear a lot when I tell other developers I’m writing a language. In case that’s your reaction, I’ll now go through some initial decisions that are made and steps that are taken when starting any new language.

paragraphs.name: 5ae3
paragraphs.text: Again, there was a decision to make involving a third party library. The predominant parsing library is Bison. Bison works a lot like Flex. You write a file in a custom format that stores the grammar information, then Bison uses that to generate a C program that will do your parsing. I did not choose to use Bison.

I’m not an expert. When I started this project, I had no clue what I was doing, and I still don’t. I’ve taken zero classes on language creation, read only a bit about it online, and did not follow much of the advice I have been given.

paragraphs.text: I love to read from kids that have ‘reinvented the wheel’. Next he will be deomonstrating binary search. Sonny, ever heard of Basic? Yeah, we used to code in that and then combine it with calls to compiled languages in the same product.

paragraphs.text: Nice post! Many years ago I had the opportunity to write a compiler and I have fond memories of that project. It’s fun. It’s interesting to see how many of the tools and patterns (e.g. Bison) are still around and being used by people. What was your motivation for creating a whole new language platform?

paragraphs.text: Nice blog. I took compiler construction as an undergrad and again in graduate school, because the class was so fun. I used the same text book, known as the “Dragon” book back then. This was back in the 1980s, and I don’t know if the book is still in use. The two instructors took two completely different approaches in both classes.
